body: I think 8.10 was the exception out of the rule because of the introduction of new features that were fixing broken behavior. For other versions, I don't see the point of being too specific. I would be fine with anything greater then 10 or 11.

Well, every Node release line includes bugfixes, so in that sense we're in the same situation now as we were with 8.x. It wasn't originally supposed to be a special exception.

I think it would be nice to make our Node requirement specific by excluding infrequently-used versions, since it reduces the likelihood of inadvertently introducing bugs on supported versions. (With our current Travis setup, we only test the latest Node release on each release line anyway, so if a bug were introduced that only affects 10.0.0, we probably wouldn't notice. We've discussed adding builds explicitly for versions like 10.0.0 in the past, but there were concerns about builds taking too long.)

However, I don't feel strongly about it and would be fine with something like `^8.10.0 || >=10.0.0` if other people are opposed to making the requirements so specific.

I mean Node 8.10 was a special case, because our code wasn't working with versions <8.10. While something like that might happen again, it's unlikely, since those fixes were more like breaking changes.
Are you sure? From what I recall, our code was working fine with Node <8.10, but we chose to only support things above that version in case we wanted to use that version's features in the future.
Hmm... You might be right. I'm a bit hazy on the details of that conversation.

issue.title: Breaking: drop Node.js 6 support (fixes #11456)

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
**What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to item)**

[X] Other, please explain: fixes #11456

**What changes did you make? (Give an overview)**

This PR changes Node.js versions ESLint supports. The new versions are `^8.10.0 || ^10.13.0 || >=11.10.1` based on that issue.

**Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?**

It's fine with the versions?

body:
**TSC Summary**: This issue proposes setting our Node version support in ESLint 6 to `^8.10.0 || ^10.13.0 || >=11.10.1`.

**TSC Question**: Should we accept this proposal?
During today's TSC meeting, we approved the minimum Node versions as `^8.10.0 || ^10.13.0 || >=11.10.1`.

issue.title: Feature Request: Upgrade to Node.js v10

repository.name: brackets
repository.description: An open source code editor for the web, written in JavaScript, HTML and CSS.

issue.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Can you reproduce the problem with `Debug -> Reload Without Extensions`?
* [x] Did you perform a cursory search to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
* [x] Did you read the [Troubleshooting guide](https://github.com/adobe/brackets/wiki/Troubleshooting)?

For more information on how to write a good bug report read [here](https://github.com/adobe/brackets/wiki/How-to-Report-an-Issue)
For more information on how to contribute read [here](https://github.com/adobe/brackets/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)

### Description

Would it be possible to start working towards upgrading Node.js to v10? Node.js v6 has already reached it's end of life.

Additionally, what actually brought me here, was that the newest version of ESLint, 6.0.1 (for use with the ESLint plugin that _ships with Brackets_, thus why I decided to report it here) does not work with Brackets. However, this is **NOT** an issue with [brackets-eslint](https://github.com/brackets-userland/brackets-eslint). Starting with ESLint 6, ESLint requires Node.js v8 and above. Brackets ships with Node.js 6.14.0.
Related issues
https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/11944
https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/11456

As a workaround, ESLint@^5.16.0 should be used.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install ESLint ^6.0.0 into the project folder as per [brackets-eslint instructions](https://github.com/brackets-userland/brackets-eslint)
2. Provide a .eslint configuration
3. Start Brackets
4. Try to use the linter

**Expected behavior:** ESLint linter messages to appear

**Actual behavior:** The ESLint pane shows an error (because brackets-eslint thinks that ESLint isn't installed)
```
NodeDebugUtils.js:111 [node-error 7:08:14 PM] [brackets-eslint] Wasn't able to load eslint from C:\Users\Ethan\Workspace\mc-mod-tool\node_modules\eslint\lib\api.js, be sure to run 'npm install' properly: C:\Users\Ethan\Workspace\mc-mod-tool\node_modules\eslint\lib\cli-engine\cli-engine.js:257
        ...calculateStatsPerFile(messages)
        ^^^

SyntaxError: Unexpected token ...
    at createScript (vm.js:56:10)
    at Object.runInThisContext (vm.js:97:10)
    at Module._compile (module.js:549:28)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:586:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:494:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:453:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:445:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:504:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:20:19)
    at Object.<anonymous> (C:\Users\Ethan\Workspace\mc-mod-tool\node_modules\eslint\lib\cli-engine\index.js:3:23)handleLogEvent @ NodeDebugUtils.js:111
```

### Versions

OS: Windows 10
Brackets: Release 1.14 build 1.14.0-17740 (release 329d08ffc)
